document_title: Sore throat: Causes, symptoms and prevention
subsection_content:
Depending on the cause of a sore throat, symptoms of a sore throat may vary.
Flu: Sore throat often accompanied by cough, fever, phlegm in the throat, bad breath, runny nose, stuffy nose, red, swollen and watery eyes and fatigue.; Bacteria: Sore throat with fever, cervical lymph nodes, tonsils with pus...; Pulmonary tuberculosis: Sore throat with severe cough, sputum mixed with blood; Gastroesophageal reflux: Stomach fluid flows up into the throat, stomach acid irritates the throat mucosa, causing heat and burning. In many cases, there is also a cough. Sore throat due to gastroesophageal reflux can be accompanied by stomach disease characterized by belching, heartburn, and frequent coughing at night. Patients will cough more at night because when sleeping, lying down makes stomach acid more susceptible to reflux.; Nasopharyngeal cancer: Sore throat is often accompanied by swollen lymph nodes in the neck, fatigue, weight loss, voice changes, and spitting up blood.; Thyroid disease: Sore throat can be accompanied by a large neck, difficulty swallowing, difficulty swallowing...
Sore throat is a non-specific symptom of many diseases, including both benign and malignant diseases. Endoscopy of the ENT area contributes to finding the cause of the disease and screening for dangerous causes. Therefore, MSc.BSc.CKI Nguyen Thi Thuc Nhu recommends that if after two weeks the symptoms do not improve, the patient should go to the hospital for a check-up and appropriate treatment.
